I well record, a holy Father sayes,</br>"He teaches to deny, that faintly prayes:"</br>The suit surceases, when desire failes,</br>But whoso prayes with fervencie, prevailes;</br>For Pray'rs the key that opens heaven gate,</br>And findes admittance, whether earl' or late,</br>It forces audience, it unlockes the eare</br>Of heavenly God (though deafe) it makes him heare.

Upon a time Babel (the Worlds faire Queene</br>Made drunke with choller, and enrag'd with Spleene)</br>Through fell Disdaine, derraigned Warre 'gainst them</br>That tender Homage to Jerusalem:</br>A Mayden fight it was, yet they were strong</br>As men of Warre; The Battaile lasted long,</br>Much bloud was shed, and spilt on either side,</br>That all the ground with purple gore was dyde:</br>In fine, a Souldier of Jerusalem:</br>Charissa hight, (the Almner of the Realme)</br>Chill'd with a Fever, and unapt to fight,</br>Into Justitia's Castle tooke her flight,</br>Whereat great Babels Queene commanded all,</br>To lay their siege against the Castle wall;</br>But poore Tymissa (not with warre acquainted)</br>Fearing Charissa's death, fell downe, and fainted;</br>Dauntlesse Prudentia rear'd her from the ground,</br>Where she lay (pale and sencelesse) in a swound,</br>She rubb'd her temples (lost in swonny shade)</br>And gave her water, that Fidissa made,</br>And said, Cheare up, (deare Sister) though our foe</br>Hath ta'ne us Captives, and inthrall'd us so,</br>We have a King puissant, and of might,</br>Will see us take no wrong, and doe us right,</br>If we possesse him with our sad complaint,</br>Cheare up, wee'l send to him, and him acquaint.</br>Timissa (new awak'd from swound) replies,</br>Our Castle is begirt with enemies,</br>And clouds of armed men besiege our walls,</br>Then suer Death, or worse than Death befalls</br>To her, (who ere she be) that stirres a foote,</br>Or dares attempt, this place to sally out:</br>Alas!  what hope have wee to finde reliefe,</br>And want the meanes that may divulge our griefe?

Within that place a jolly Matron won'd,</br>With fierie lookes, and drawen-sword in hond,</br>Her eyes, with age, were waxen wond'rous dim,</br>With hoary locks, and visage stern, and grim;</br>Her name Justitia hight; to her they make</br>Their moane, who (well-advis'd) them thus bespake:

"Faire Maydens, well I wot; y'are ill bedight,</br>And rue the suffrance of your wofull plight,</br>But Pitty's fond alone, rankles griefe,</br>But fruitlesse falls, unlesse it yeeld reliefe:</br>Cheare up, I have a Messenger in store,</br>Whose speed is much, but faithfull trust is more,</br>Whose nimble wings shall cleave the flitting skies,</br>And scorne the terrour of your enemies,</br>Oratio hight, well knowne unto your King,</br>Your message she shall doe, and tydings bring,</br>Provided that Fidissa travaile with her,</br>And so (on Christs name) let them goe together.</br>With that, Fidissa having ta'ne her errant,</br>And good Oratio, with Justitia's Warrant,</br>In silence of the midnight, tooke their flight,</br>Arriving at the Court that very night;</br>But they were both as any fier hot,</br>For they did flie as swift, as Cannon shot,</br>But they (lest suddaine cold should doe them harme)</br>Together clung, and kept each other warme:</br>But lo, the Kingly gates were sparr'd, and lockt,</br>They call'd, but none made answere, then they knockt,</br>Together joyning both their force in one,</br>They knockt amaine; Yet answere there was none;</br>But they that never learn'd to take deniall,</br>With importunity made further triall;</br>The King heard well, although he list not speake,</br>Till they with strokes the gate did wel-nie breake.</br>In fine, the brazen gates flew open wide;</br>Oratio moov'd her suit:  The King replide,</br>Oratio was a faire, and welcome ghest;</br>So heard her suit; so graunted her request.</br>Fraile Man, observe, In thee the practice lies,</br>Let sacred Meditation moralize.</br>Let Pray'r be fervent, and thy Faith intire,</br>And God will graunt thee more then thy desire.</br>
